text: Patient: Tomorrow I’m going to this local one. I have a schedule with Dr. ___in January because the last neurologist that I saw, the one that put the catheter in, told me the catheter should not be taken out in less than four to six weeks. It should be replaced in every four to six weeks if necessary. Doctor: Sure. Patient: So when I talked to ___, he said okay, then come in January and then we’ll that procedure. So I don’t know if I should go there. I don’t even know what else he can do. I didn’t have chance to talk to him personally. I talked to nurse and she did not explain correctly. Looks like he can’t do anything for me except the nurse is taking catheter out and putting it in. So what other treatments he’s going to give me, I don’t know. Doctor: Dr. ____ or Patient: Dr. ____. Doctor: And the issue really is we’d like to get the catheter out and sort of when is your bladder strong enough to take it out, if we’ve shrunk the cancer with the hormone therapy – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - is there enough of a channel for you to pee on our own? Doctor: So all of that – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - is what urologists do. Patient: Right, I know. So anyway, I have it scheduled.

text: Patient: Hmm. Doctor: That trial is going to take the immune system idea to the max which is okay if, more importantly, the reason is, not to oversell, but one of the things with prostate cancer that we see is, when you look at other cancers under the microscope, you see the immune system trying at least. You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there. Patient: I see. Doctor: So how, so a lot of the research is how do we get those cells attractive- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to go in the cancer? And the most extreme way would be give you a new immune system. Give you somebody else’s immune system where those cancers were foreign. Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh so right now you’re eligible for that. Maybe put that on the back burner. The one thing that would make you ineligible is going on chemotherapy.

text: Patient: My hip primarily, the hip and lumbar region. Doctor: And that’s your right hip? Patient: Right hip, yeah and then that was ten doses and the lower femur, five doses of treatments. Doctor: And how are you feeling? Patient: Pretty good. Doctor: How’s your pain? Patient: No pain. There’s just a little; I know my right hip is there. You know I know what the sensation is. Doctor: So the radiation helped? Patient: Yes, I think so, yes. Doctor: But you still need to take the opioids. Patient: Yeah, yeah, but not as much. I’ve cut down. Doctor: So the OxyContin was two times a day and now you’re once a day.

text: Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month?

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: and twelve months later your PSA is stabilizes Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Um, hum. And that is Doctor: In your case, if I would have to guess with your PSA track record – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - your PSA was a fourteen in September and then it was twenty-eight January. Doctor: So based on that trajectory, if I had to guess, your PSA is still at the same place, so to speak, it will take about half that amount of time for your PSA to go about fifty percent. And um because the trial involves radiation therapy being delivered by a radiology oncologist. text: Patient: - seminal vesicles and (patient talking over doctor) Doctor: So when we talk about side effects there’s always the potential – Patient: Right. Doctor: - for you know unintended injury to things in that area like the bladder, the urethra, ah the colon which - or the rectum which sits right behind. Patient: Sure. Doctor: You can have things like blood in the urine. You can have problems with healing in that area. That’s why we don’t automatically refer people immediately… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …after surgery because we want the healing process to be well established before we throw in kind of a wild card like radiation that Patient: Mmm. Doctor: might have some impact on healing. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
